story.headline: Small Islands Face Existential Threat From Intensifying Storms
story.summary: St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a small island developing state in the Caribbean, faces increasingly severe hurricanes and tropical storms. Warmer ocean temperatures are fueling more intense and rapid-onset storms.
story.climateImpact: Climate change is increasing sea surface temperatures, which drives stronger hurricane formation. For small island nations, a single Category 4 or 5 storm can devastate the entire economy.
causeEffect: Warmer ocean temperatures fuel stronger hurricanes
Sea level rise amplifies storm surge damage
Rapid intensification makes storms harder to prepare for
Infrastructure damage exceeds GDP, crippling recovery
story.scaleContext: Hurricane Beryl in 2024 became the earliest Category 5 Atlantic hurricane in recorded history. Storm damage costs in the Caribbean often exceed 200% of a nation's annual GDP.
story.outlook: Without global emissions reductions and increased climate finance for adaptation, small island states face repeated catastrophic losses and potential uninhabitability.

title: Small Islands Face Existential Threat From Intensifying Storms
summary: St. Vincent and the Grenadines faces increasingly severe hurricanes driven by warmer ocean temperatures, with damage costs often exceeding annual GDP.
